title: Fox Theatre (Detroit)
text:
The Fox Theatre is a performing arts center located at 2211 Woodward Avenue in <a href="Downtown%20Detroit">Downtown Detroit</a>, <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>, near the <a href="Grand%20Circus%20Park%20Historic%20District">Grand Circus Park Historic District</a>. Opened in 1928 as a flagship <a href="movie%20palace">movie palace</a> in the <a href="Fox%20Theatres">Fox Theatres</a> chain, it was at over 5,000 seats the largest theater in the city. Designed by theater architect <a href="C.%20Howard%20Crane">C. Howard Crane</a>, it was listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> in 1985 and was designated a <a href="List%20of%20National%20Historic%20Landmarks%20in%20Michigan">National Historic Landmark</a> in 1989 for its architecture. The area surrounding the Fox is nicknamed "Foxtown". The city's major <a href="Theatre%20in%20Detroit">performance centers and theatres</a> emanate from the Fox Theatre and <a href="Grand%20Circus%20Park%20Historic%20District">Grand Circus Park Historic District</a> and continue along <a href="Woodward%20Avenue">Woodward Avenue</a> toward the <a href="Fisher%20Building">Fisher Theatre</a> in the city's <a href="New%20Center%2C%20Detroit">New Center</a>.
The Fox has 5,048 seats (5,174 seats if removable seats placed in the raised orchestra pit are included). It is the largest surviving movie palace of the 1920s and the largest of the original Fox Theatres. The Fox was fully restored in 1988. The adjacent office building houses the headquarters of <a href="Olympia%20Entertainment">Olympia Entertainment</a> and <a href="Little%20Caesars">Little Caesars</a>.
History.
The Detroit Fox is one of five spectacular <a href="Fox%20Theatres">Fox Theatres</a> built in the late 1920s by film pioneer <a href="William%20Fox%20%28producer%29">William Fox</a>. The others were the Fox Theatres in Brooklyn, <a href="Fox%20Theatre%20%28Atlanta%2C%20Georgia%29">Atlanta</a>, <a href="Fox%20Theatre%20%28St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri%29">St. Louis</a>, and <a href="Fox%20Theatre%20%28San%20Francisco%2C%20California%29">San Francisco</a>. Architect <a href="C.%20Howard%20Crane">C. Howard Crane</a> designed the Fox with a lavish interior featuring a blend of <a href="Burma">Burmese</a>, <a href="China">Chinese</a>, <a href="India">India</a>n and <a href="Iran">Persian</a> motifs. There are three levels of seating, the Main Floor above the orchestra pit, the Mezzanine, and the Gallery (balcony). The exterior of the attached 10-story office building features a façade with Asian motifs which, when illuminated at night, can be seen for several blocks. The <a href="Fox%20Theatre%20%28St.%20Louis%29">Fox Theatre</a> in <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a> is (on the interior) its near architectural twin with about 500 fewer seats. The 10-story Detroit Fox Theatre building also contains the headquarters of <a href="Olympia%20Entertainment">Olympia Entertainment</a>, while the St. Louis Fox is a stand-alone theatre. The architectural plaster molds of the Detroit Fox (1928) were re-used on the St. Louis Fox (1929).
The Fox opened in 1928 and remained Detroit's premier movie destination for decades. Unlike many neighboring theatres, it operated continually until it was closed in the 1980s for restoration. However, by the 1960s, the venue was showing its age and maintenance of many key areas was deferred. By the 1970s <a href="mezzanine">mezzanine</a> and <a href="balcony">balcony</a> seating areas were closed to the public.
In 1984 Chuck Forbes, owner of the <a href="Fillmore%20Detroit">State</a> and Gem theaters, proposed a renovation project. These plans were never fully realized, but in 1988 the theater was acquired by new owners, <a href="Mike%20Ilitch">Mike</a> and <a href="Marian%20Bayoff%20Ilitch">Marian Ilitch</a>, who fully restored the Fox at a cost of $12 million. Their company, <a href="Ilitch%20Holdings%2C%20Inc.">Ilitch Holdings, Inc.</a>, is headquartered in the Fox Theater Office Building. The downtown area near <a href="Grand%20Circus%20Park%20Historic%20District">Grand Circus Park</a> which encompasses Fox Theatre is sometimes referred to as "Foxtown" after the theater. In 2000, <a href="Comerica%20Park">Comerica Park</a> opened and helped to revitalize the neighborhood along with the construction of <a href="Ford%20Field">Ford Field</a> in 2002, and <a href="Little%20Caesars%20Arena">Little Caesars Arena</a> in 2017.
Productions.
The gala opening took place September 21, 1928, and featured the silent film <a href="Street%20Angel%20%281928%20film%29">"Street Angel"</a> starring Janet Gaynor. The live show depicted a history of Detroit from its settlement in 1701 to the present. Productions included feature-length movies, shorts and newsreels, and performances by the 60-piece Fox Theatre Grand Orchestra, a 50-voice choir and a 32-member chorus line called the Tillerettes. This was Fox's version of producer <a href="Samuel%20Roxy%20Rothafel">Samuel "Roxy" Rothafel's</a> <a href="The%20Rockettes">Roxyettes</a>.
In the 1930s, Shirley Temple made appearances when the theater showed her films. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, like many theaters in the area, the Fox operated 24 hours a day to accommodate defense plant workers on afternoon and evening shifts. The theater routinely grossed $75,000 a week when admission was 35 cents. In 1953, the theater was the first in Michigan equipped for <a href="CinemaScope">CinemaScope</a> and premiered the epic picture <a href="The%20Robe%20%28film%29">"The Robe"</a>.
In May 1956, the theater hosted three performances by <a href="Elvis%20Presley">Elvis Presley</a>. During the 1960s, the theater hosted performances by many <a href="Motown">Motown</a> recording artists, but by the 1970s the theater was showing its age. Unlike other downtown Detroit theaters in the 1970s, such as the <a href="Michigan%20Theatre%20%28Detroit%2C%20Michigan%29">Michigan</a> and <a href="United%20Artists%20Theatre%20Building">United Artists</a>, the Fox was able to remain open by programming <a href="Blaxploitation">Blaxploitation</a> and <a href="martial%20arts%20films">martial arts films</a>.
The first production at the Fox after restoration was a November 19, 1988, concert with Joe Williams and the <a href="Count%20Basie%20Orchestra">Count Basie Orchestra</a>. Since then, notable performances include a concert with <a href="Frank%20Sinatra">Frank Sinatra</a>, <a href="Sammy%20Davis%20Jr.">Sammy Davis Jr.</a> and <a href="Liza%20Minnelli">Liza Minnelli</a> which was recorded and broadcast on the <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a> cable network in 1989 and a 1990 performance by <a href="Victor%20Borge">Victor Borge</a> which was recorded for broadcast on <a href="Public%20Broadcasting%20Service">PBS</a> and later incorporated into his DVD "Victor Borge: Then and Now". The theater hosted the <a href="WWE%20Hall%20of%20Fame">WWE Hall of Fame</a> ceremony on March 31, 2007, the night before <a href="WrestleMania%2023">WrestleMania 23</a> was held at nearby <a href="Ford%20Field">Ford Field</a>. The prior evening, March 30, 2007, the theater hosted the world premiere of the film <a href="The%20Condemned">The Condemned</a>.
Live productions have included touring companies of "<a href="Sesame%20Street%20Live">Sesame Street Live</a>: Let's Be Friends", <a href="David%20Copperfield%20%28illusionist%29">David Copperfield</a>, "Blue's Clues Live!", <a href="Fairuz">Fairuz</a>, <a href="Donny%20Osmond">Donny Osmond</a>, "<a href="Irving%20Berlin%27s%20White%20Christmas">Irving Berlin's White Christmas</a>", "Dora The Explorer Live", "Go! Diego! Live!" and "<a href="What%27s%20Done%20in%20the%20Dark">What's Done in the Dark</a>" and "<a href="Riverdance">Riverdance</a>". The <a href="Radio%20City%20Christmas%20Spectacular">Radio City Christmas Spectacular</a> was an annual favorite from 1997 through 2005. Both the interior and exterior of The Fox were used in a <a href="Chrysler">Chrysler</a> <a href="Born%20of%20Fire">commercial</a> for its <a href="Chrysler%20200">Chrysler 200</a>, featuring <a href="Eminem">Eminem</a>, that <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLV%23Advertising">aired</a> during <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLV">Super Bowl XLV</a> in February 2011.
Detroit's Fox Theatre has hosted the following <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a> musicians: <a href="Aretha%20Franklin">Aretha Franklin</a> in 1994 and 2012, <a href="Hall%20%26amp%3B%20Oates">Hall & Oates</a> in 1990, <a href="The%20Temptations">The Temptations</a> in 1988, <a href="Stevie%20Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a> in 1969, <a href="The%20Spinners%20%28American%20R%26amp%3BB%20group%29">The Spinners</a> in 1977, <a href="Smokey%20Robinson">Smokey Robinson</a> in 1988, <a href="Al%20Green">Al Green</a> in 1989, <a href="Diana%20Ross">Diana Ross</a> in 1990, <a href="Alice%20Cooper">Alice Cooper</a> in 1990, <a href="Iggy%20Pop">Iggy Pop</a> and <a href="The%20Stooges">The Stooges</a> in 2007, <a href="Kid%20Rock">Kid Rock</a> in 2012, <a href="Jack%20White">Jack White</a> in 2014, and <a href="Greta%20Van%20Fleet">Greta Van Fleet</a> in 2018. <a href="Chris%20Cornell">Chris Cornell</a> of Soundgarden played his final show there on May 17, 2017.
On July 30 and 31, 2019, the theatre was the site of a two-night <a href="2020%20Democratic%20debates">primary debate</a> among the announced candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for the 2020 presidential race.
Architecture.
The Fox Office Building, which forms the Woodward façade of the theatre, is 10 stories in height. The front and sides of the office tower are faced with a cream-colored terra cotta. There are decorative <a href="lintel%20%28architecture%29">lintels</a> above the windows on the second and tenth floor. The building wraps around the theatre lobby creating a u-shaped floor plan. The auditorium and rear of the office tower are faced with brick.
The current marquee was installed during the 1987 restoration but is based on the original which itself was replaced in the 1950s.
The original configuration of the street and second floors contained 20 retail spaces on each level. Spaces featured large display windows looking into the corridors and ground floor spaces also had access directly from the street.
Office space occupied the third through tenth floor and featured marble floors and wainscoting in the corridors. Office doors featured full-length glass with glass transoms above to allow light and ventilation into the corridors. Many of these features remained when the 1987 restoration began with the exception of the seventh floor which was altered in the 1970s to accommodate a <a href="Social%20Security%20%28United%20States%29">Social Security Administration</a> office.
The theatre entrance on Woodward has 16 doors that open onto the storm lobby with a black and white marble floor and small ornate plaster alcoves in the ceiling. The storm lobby opens into the main lobby which is approximately deep and six floors high. The floor is terrazzo with brass inlays but it was unseen until the 1988 renovation. Lore says that Eve Leo, wife of Fox President William Fox, was unhappy when she learned that the theatre was to have a bare floor. She insisted it needed carpeting, so it was covered with what was the largest single-piece wool rug ever manufactured. The rug covered of the lobby floor and weighed .
Above the entrance doors are faux organ pipes fashioned from plaster and in a balcony to the upper left is a 3-manual, 13-rank <a href="M.%20P.%20Moller">Moller</a> organ with the real pipes in the chamber above the console. The Fox's Moller is the only one still in situ. On each side of the lobby are eight vermillion <a href="scagliola">scagliola</a> columns. The columns rise from black octagonal bases and are adorned with eagles, flowers, glass jewels highlighted by silver leaf to a height of approximately . The Corinthian capitals are also silver leafed and bear images of a variety of animals and birds. The columns support plaster beams decorated with faces, starbursts and cartouches. Between the columns are small balconies on the mezzanine and balcony levels that overlook the main floor. The ceiling is blue with a sunburst design surrounded by Fox griffins. At the rear of the lobby, the grand staircase leads to the mezzanine level. Two plaster lions with jeweled eyes guard the base of the stairs and fish-like creatures adorn the balustrades. On the mezzanine level, four additional columns frame two-story windows enclosing the auditorium. A loggia above the windows allows patrons on the balcony level to look down into the lobby.
Beside the grand stairs are doors leading to the 2,898 orchestra-level seats. The auditorium is high and wide. An inner lobby wraps around the seating area and contains two oval stairways leading to upper seating levels and the lounges on the lower level. The walls of the auditorium are shades of beige and are adorned with molded plaster plants, human faces, geometric designs, birds and animals.
The proscenium is and high. Like the side walls, it is adorned with animals, human figures, starbursts and flowers. Above the center of the proscenium is an elephant's head. Suspended below the elephant is a large quatrefoil-shaped censer that conceals speakers. The backstage area originally had 18 performer dressing rooms, offices and a broadcast booth. In the basement were staff dressing rooms, workshops, an infirmary, screening room and storage rooms.
The orchestra pit and sections of the stage can be raised and lowered on hydraulic lifts. The stage is wide, deep and houses the four-manual 36-rank <a href="Wurlitzer">Wurlitzer</a> organ. This organ was constructed especially for the theatre and is one of the few <a href="theatre%20organ">theatre organ</a>s in the world that remains in its original installation.
On the side walls at the orchestra level are Moorish arches extending to the balcony. Above is a colonnade at the balcony level with nine vermillion scagiolia columns matching those in the lobby. The columns support decorated arches and behind the first three are grilles that conceal the bays containing the 2,700 pipes and other effects for the organ. The areas between the other columns are filled with tinted mirrors. The walls are topped with a cornice decorated with lion and human faces set among geometric designs and sunbursts.
The ceiling is designed to resemble a round tent with an oculus supported by spears. The tent drapes slightly and is covered with acoustical felt bearing a stenciled design. The ceiling of the oculus is blue with a globe chandelier of colored glass suspended from a starburst design. The chandelier is in diameter weighs and contains 1200 pieces of glass.
The projection booth was one of the largest of its day and originally housed four projectors, three spotlights and a <a href="Brenkert%20Brenograph%20Jr.">Brenograph Machine</a> to produce special effects.
